A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. document.text: PAMPLIN - J. Aubrey Gilliam, age 93, died Tuesday, Sept. 9, at his residence near Pamplin. Born June 6, 1882 in Appomattox County he was the husband of the late Lona Reynolds Gilliam and the son of the late John James Gilliam and Cordelia North Gilliam. He was a retired dairy farmer and a life long and also the oldest member of Eton Baptist Church in Pamplin. He served as treasurer and superintendent of this church. Mr. Gilliam is survived by four sons J. 0. Gilliam of Lynchburg C. W. Gilliam and J. A. Gilliam, Jr., both of Pamplin R. W. Gilliam of Richmond and four daughters, Mrs. H. E. Carwile, Sr. of Pamplin Mrs. R. M. Harris of Spout Spring Mrs. C. L. Carwile of Cullen and Mrs. Frank Clarkson of Pamplin. He was also survived by one brother, H. W. Gilliam of Carlysle, Pa. 19 grandchildren, 34 great-grandchildren 7 great great grandchildren 4 step grandchildren 9 step great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, Sept. 11, at 2 at Elon Baptist Church in Pamplin and interment will be in the Olive Branch United Methodist Cemetery near Prospect. The family will receive Shorter Funeral Home in Appomattox was in charge of arrangement.

While running to the fire one of the Sarah Zane Fire Companys horses fell over a - pile of stone in the dark and was severely in jured. Mrs. Virginia Bond, widow of Thoma Bond, died at her home near Oronage Courthouse, aged 62 years. She is sur vived by two, sons and two sisters. The portrait of George Washington, owned in Fredericksburg by Masoni Lodge No. 4, which made him a Mason, has been pronounced by experts in Wash ington a genuine Gilbert Stuart paint ing. As Stuarts works are rare, this j original portrait is of considerable value. This is said to have been painted from life during Washingtons second term as President of the United States. Tra dition says it was a gift of Washington to his mother lodge. A young daughter of Mr. Amos Sulli van, of Stafford county, was badly burn ed last week by falling into an open fire. There was indignation in Norfolk on the receipt of the Congressional Record, which declares that the item in the River and Harbor bill as passed au thorizes a 25 and 30-foot channel to the navy yard in the Elizabeth river when the bill was drawn for a 30 and 35-foot channel. The channel is already 28 feet deep and vessels of 30-foot draft have passed out. If the item in the Congres sional Record be not a misprint the bill must have been tampered with. Phila delphia interests are suspected here. Benjamin Lovitt, a negro boy, was arraigned in Berkley, charged itith the malicious wounding of John Allen, son of D. V. Allen. Allen and other white boys were playing marbles when the negro boys approached and a quarrel en sued. Allen was stabbed in the back with a pocketknife. The wound is seri ous, and Lovitt is held to await the re- sult. The explosion of a bottle of nitre in the drug , store of Jerome P. Carr, of Portsmouth, set the place on fire. Smith, chancellor of the Randolph-Macon System of Col leges, purposes to enlarge the Womans College at Lynchburg. He wants to raise 40,000 by subscriptions if the City Coun cil of Lynchburg will appropriate 10,- 000 to make the amount 50,000. Dr. Smith offers to erect during this year a science hall, costing 20,000, and an addi tional dormitory, which will aid him in increasing the attendance by too young ladies, if the city will make the asked for appropriation. This will bring the enrollment up to 550. Four prisoners escaped from the Lex ington Jail. They are John H. Maz- ingo, sentenced to four years in the pen itentiary for house-breaking S. C. Van landingham, sentenced to 12 months in jail for selling liquor in a local-option district, and Jack Lamb and Wade Gra ham, awaiting trial for house-breaking. The prisoners secured braces from their iron bedsteads and pried several bar from the bottom of the iron door. Crawling under the iron door, they used the bars as levers with which they pried open the outer wooden door leading into the hallway. They then pried the lock from the back door and escaped through the back yard. Page, of the new Tidewater railway, which is to parallel the Norfolk and Western from Nor folk to the mountains, advertised for bids for the grading and masonry of 20 sectibris of the road, a distance of 100 miles west from Sewalls Point through Norfolk.
